page.title: 18Conservation of wildlife.
page.content: Conserving wildlife has become an important theme in the teaching of the College of Agriculture. Students are encouraged to consider wildlife when farming. Within the College's farm hedges are left whenever possible and new 'shelter belts' planted to provide cover for the creatures to move around without being detected. A meadow, originally a wild garden has remained free of chemical fertilizers and weed killers since 1900. One cut of hay is taken in August and sheep are allowed to graze in non growing seasons to keep the grass down. Daffodil Meadow, as it is called, is covered, in season, by daffodils, cowslips,buttercups,clovers and vetches. Varieties of wild orchid are also found including the Early Purple, the Butterfly and recently Bee Orchids.
